en-us.learning_promise:
**Learning Promise**
In this unit, your students will be introduced to the world of robotics competitions as they gradually learn the basics of building and programming autonomous robots using sensors. Working together to build an effective competition robot, they'll systematically test and refine programs, using the design process to develop a solution in order to complete missions, all the while developing skills related to collaboration and teamwork, and life skills for their future careers.

lessons.lesson_description: Build a Practice Driving Base and make precise and controlled movements.
lessons.lesson_sub_title: Controlling Movements using the Gyro Sensor
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Two wheels. Check! Two motors. Check! How can you drive forward, backward, left, right, and even in circles? What‘s the best way to get from one side of an object to the other, without bumping into it? Let’s figure out how to make controlled movements.

step.title: Let's learn some competition field tactics!

text.content:
Navigating around obstacles is a key to success on the robotics competition field.

Can you list all the movements you think your Driving Base should be able do?

This is a simple but effective way to learn some field tactics:
* A Practice Driving Base

If you have time, build your own design.

step.title: Try these programming stacks one after the other.

comments.comment: This stack defines the parameters of your Driving Base.
When the program starts, your Driving Base should turn 90 degrees using the Gyro Sensor in the Hub.
When the Left Button on the Hub is pressed, your Driving Base should move forward and backward.
When the Right Button on the Hub is pressed, your Driving Base should move in a circular motion.
You can also create 3 separate programs and download them in different memory positions on your Hub. That way you can play them individually.

What do you see? 

Change the values of each block’s parameters and see what happens.

step.title: Make your Driving Base move in a square.

text.content: Pick actions from the stacks that are already on the Programming Canvas.

Use a repeat Loop in your program.

What action do you need to repeat to make your Driving Base to move in a square?

Here’s an example:

step.title: Time for a field tactics challenge!

text.content: Place 8 colored bricks on a surface and use your programming skills to cross the “field” without touching the bricks.

Develop your programming skills by writing the pseudocode first.

For example:
* Move forward to "this point"
* Turn of about 45 degrees
* Move backward "a little"

This list is called pseudocode.

Think about what you did well and what you could’ve done better.

Great start on avoiding obstacles!

lessons.title: SPIKE Training Camp 1 Driving Around

lessons.lesson_description: Use sensors to control motors and interact with objects on the competition field.
lessons.lesson_sub_title: Controlling Movements Using the Distance Sensor
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Pick it up, push it around. Now, move around it without touching it! In robotics competitions, you have to know how to interact with objects in specific ways. Let’s figure out how to do this.

step.title: Most games have an object to interact with.

text.content:
For example, relay race runners must pick up and hand off the baton with speed and accuracy.

Can you think of other examples?

We’ll use them one at a time.
* Practice Driving Base with a Distance Sensor
* Arm
* Marker
* Cube

step.title: Stop at object: with or without sensor?

comments.comment: This stack moves the Driving Base without detecting the object.
This stack moves the Driving Base with object detection.

text.content:
Place your Driving Base 30 cm (12 in.) away from the marker.

Try these 2 programming stacks one at a time and decide which is best.
One of the stacks uses the Distance Sensor to detect the object in front of the Driving Base.

step.title: Drive forward and grab the cube.

text.content:
Add extra programming blocks to your programming stack to make it:
* Lower the grabber after stopping at the marker
* Reverse and move the cube away from the marker
Here’s one way to solve this:

text.content:
Create a relay race program.

Will you be the fastest?

Check the hint for the rules of the game.

Here are the rules:

> 1. Set a distance of 12 in.
> 2. Break the cube into four different colored relay batons.
> 3. Program your Practice Driving Base to collect all of the colored batons one at a time from the marker. 
> 4. Remove each baton from the Practice Driving Base as it’s delivered.

What did you do well? Is there anything you could’ve done better?

Looking good!

text.content:
It's easy to win a car race. Mostly, you just need to be the fastest, and stay on your racing lane.

Would it help if you could follow a line?

When the Right Button on the Hub is pressed, your Driving Base will follow a parallel line.

text.content: Try the first programming stack and describe what you see.

This first stack will make the Driving Base stop at a line that’s perpendicular to its movement. 

The line can be:
* Drawn on the table
* On a piece of paper
* The black axle element
Try the second programming stack and describe what you see.

When the Color Sensor detects the edge of the black line, the Driving Base turns in the direction of the white space.

When the Color Sensor detects the white space, the Driving Base turns in the other direction, toward the edge of black line.

Repeat these 2 actions forever.

Maybe you have noticed that we are turning motors using the Power mode? Do you know why?

As your driving base needs to perform small and fast movements (most likely bellow 10 degrees each time between the white and the black space), programming using Power Mode makes a more reactive, and more accurate line follower.

There are many ways to make a fast line-follower.

Organize a race to see whose Driving Base can go the fastest!

Add an ”IF ELSE” Block to speed up the execution of the program.

Keep exploring line-follower programs, you’ll be surprised how much you can improve your speed!
Your program could look something like this:

lessons.student_worksheet_description: It’s time to get your robot onto the FIRST LEGO League game field. Let’s learn how to solve the first mission and prepare for the rest of the challenges! Are you in?

text.content:
Have you ever seen a rescue helicopter?
Discuss reasons why helicopters get used instead of other types of transport.

You’ll need a Driving Base to solve the mission.
Build any desired modifications to the robot.
Visit the building instructions page for inspiration.
Make sure the Guided Mission model is placed correctly on the FIRST LEGO League game field.
Don’t forget to use Dual Lock to secure the model to the mat.

text.content:
Play this program and see what it does.
Make sure you start with your Driving Base in the right position.
Use your new skills to get to another mission model.

Don’t forget to decompose the challenges you saw in the video. Break them down into smaller parts.
* Position the Driving Base.
* Follow the line.
* Get close to the mission model.
* Activate the mission model.

Use My Blocks to help you manage the program.

What did you do well? Is there anything you could’ve done better?
Now you’re ready for your next mission!

lessons.student_worksheet_description: Do you work well together? Let’s find out! Use teamwork to build a competition-ready Driving Base.

text.content:
A competition team is expected to know everything about their Driving Base.

How will you make sure your whole team is involved in building it?
Working together as a team, build this Advanced Driving Base.

building_instruction.title: SPIKE Competition-Ready Advance Driving Base Parts

text.content:
When everyone in your team has finished building, put the 4 parts together to make one Driving Base. Don’t forget:
* Cable connections
* Cable management

text.content: Try this program and see what happens.

Your Driving Base should :
* Move forward 
* Move backward
* Turn

Pretend you’re giving a short presentation to a competition judge.

How is this Driving Base different from other Driving Bases?

Talk about:
* How your Driving Base feels
* Whether or not the modular build was useful
* Why the wheels are also supported on the outside

Think about what you did well and how you could improve for next time.

Keep improving your Advanced Driving Base so it looks cool and does what you want.

lessons.title: SPIKE Assembling An Advanced Driving Base

lessons.lesson_description: Use My Blocks to write organized programs that'll help the Advanced Driving Base perform quickly and reliably.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Be the fastest and most reliable team on the field. Be the team that everyone wants to be! Let’s get better at writing and organizing programs to help your Advanced Driving Base be the best in any competition.

text.content:
Competition teams can’t touch their Driving Base while it’s running.

How will you make sure that everyone is involved in writing reliable programs?
Build these markers and place them 50 cm (20 in.) apart.

text.content:
What does it do?

A My Block is a way to create a group of actions that can be repeated whenever you need them.
This My Block will make your Advanced Driving Base move forward for 2 rotations.

Create a My Block that’ll make your Driving Base drive in a square.

Play your program whenever you‘re ready!

Press the “Make a Block” button and name it "Drive-Square."

Add whichever programming block is needed to drive in a square under the “Define Drive-Square” hat.

Add your “drive in a square” block under the “drive straight” block and play the program!

Watch the video above and figure out which My Blocks you need. 

Create and test your programs.

Each member of your team can work on a different shape before you combine your blocks:
* Drive in a square
* Drive in a circle
* Drive in a triangle

Are you pleased with your performance? Is there anything you could’ve done better?

My Blocks are a fantastic way to simplify your programs and work as a team.

lessons.title: SPIKE My Code Our Program

lessons.lesson_description: Build motorized tools that can help solve competition tasks.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: So, you can drive around and that's definitely awesome! But can you move stuff around? Let’s figure out how to use Driving Base tools to help you solve competition tasks and bring home the honors!

text.content:
During competitions, Driving Bases need specific tools to do specific tasks.

What tools would your Driving Base need in order to move objects around?

Build these tools:
* Dozer Blade, to push.
* Lift Arm, to lift.
* Crates, to move.

text.content: Write a program that copies the behavior you see in this video.
This is called “decomposing a problem.”

Are you pleased with your performance? Is there anything you could’ve done better?

If you’ve reached this point, you must be ready for a mission!

lessons.title: SPIKE Time For An Upgrade

lessons.lesson_description: Use controlled motor movements, sensors, and organized programs to solve a practice competition challenge in the shortest amount of time.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Things are about to get real! Use your training to solve this competition challenge in the shortest amount time.

text.content: Now that you've got the skills, you must be ready for a real challenge!

Follow these building instructions:
* Game module
* Path
* 2 Markers
* 4 Crates

Identify the challenges in the video and write pseudocode to solve them.

Create and test your program.

Break down the challenge into smaller tasks:
* Unlock the gate
* Open the gate
* Follow the path
* Collect the Crates

Use My Blocks to help you manage your program.

step.title: Now solve this mission as quickly as possible!

text.content:
Alright you've solved it. But can you optimize your performance?

Find ways to spend less time solving the mission.
"Optimize" means to make it more efficient, more precise, or just better in general.
Think about what you did well and what you could’ve done better.

Congratulations!

Now you really are “Competition Ready!
